w:r.w:t: The course starts from where Physics 11 left off with the study of motion. Students will explore dynamics, circular motion, energy, electricity and magnetism. The course requires a strong foundation in mathematics. The course emphasizes problem-solving and exploration.
Measurement of motion depends on our frame of reference.
Forces can cause linear and circular motion.
Forces and energy interactions occur within fields.
Momentum is conserved within a closed and isolated system.
Collaborate to plan, carry out, and review constructions and activities
Explain/recount and reflect on experiences and accomplishments
Contributing to community and caring for the environment
Demonstrate a sustained intellectual curiosity about a scientific topic or problem of personal interest
Make observations aimed at identifying their own questions, including increasingly complex ones, about the natural world
Formulate multiple hypotheses and predict multiple outcomes
Collaboratively and individually plan, select, and use appropriate investigation methods, including field work and lab experiments, to collect reliable data (qualitative and quantitative)
Assess risks and address ethical, cultural, and/or environmental issues associated with their proposed methods and those of others
Use appropriate SI units and appropriate equipment, including digital
Apply the concepts of accuracy and precision to experimental procedures
Processing and analyzing data and information
Experience and interpret the local environment
Apply First Peoples perspectives and knowledge, other ways of knowing, and local knowledge as sources of information
Seek and analyze patterns, trends, and connections in data, including describing relationships between variables (dependent and independent) and identifying inconsistencies
Construct, analyze, and interpret graphs (including interpolation and extrapolation), models, and/or diagrams
Use knowledge of scientific concepts to draw conclusions that are consistent with evidence
Evaluate the validity and limitations of a model or analogy in relation to the phenomenon
Demonstrate an awareness of assumptions, question information given, and identify bias
Consider social, ethical, and environmental implications of the findings from their own
Critically analyze the validity of information in primary and secondary sources and evaluate
Critically analyze the validity of information in secondary sources and evaluate the approaches used to solve problems
Contribute to care for self, others, community, and world through individual or collaborative approaches
Transfer and apply learning to new situations
Generate and introduce new or refined ideas when problem solving
Contribute to finding solutions to problems at a local and/or global level through inquiry
Consider the role of scientists in innovation
Formulate physical or mental theoretical models to describe a phenomenon

Communicate scientific ideas, claims, information, and perhaps a suggested course of action, for a specific purpose and audience, constructing evidence-based arguments and using appropriate scientific language, conventions, and representations
Express and reflect on a variety of experiences, perspectives, and worldviews through place, and practices
Students are expected to know the following:
First Peoples knowledge and applications of forces
English Language Strategies, Indigenous Learning, Time Frame and Summary of Assessment
Various English language learning strategies will be embedded throughout the course. Some of the common strategies and activities include:
Vocabulary words will be highlighted and practiced by the students.
Assessments (formative and summative) will include vocabulary and language components to support learning.
Large summative language-based projects will be scaffolded with checkpoints to ensure students have the linguistic capabilities to engage in the learning activities
Students will have numerous opportunities to develop oral speaking skills through structured activities such as discussions, think-pair-share, and group work working on various mathematical concepts.
Materials provided will be supported by high quality visuals to connect the language to ideas in an intuitive way.
Lecture notes (as PowerPoint slides a heavily animated) will be available to students online so that that can go though the material at their own pace.
I will work with the class to foster an open and safe environment that embiggens the opportunities for each student to speak.

First People’s principles will be embedded throughout the course. For example I will try to make the learning process holistic, reflexive, reflective, experiential, and relational [focused on connectedness, on reciprocal relationships, and a sense of place];
The class and I will strive to realize that learning involves patience and time. Also that learning is different for everyone.
Circulating the room during conceptual understanding questions
Gauging the needs of the class based on common questions that I get from the homework
During lectures: have students try a question before I do it
Providing answer keys to pre-tests and tests that students can do self-corrections
Student submissions for activities and projects
I can set realistic goals, use strategies to accomplish them, and persevere with challenging tasks.
